questions.text: Relative bradycardia is seen in which of the following infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Brucellosis

 

Explanation:

Relative bradycardia is where a person's pulse rate is lower than expected for their body temperature.

Causes include

-Exotoxin mediated vagal stimulation

-Cytokines liberated like in COVID 19 that may reset the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center and affect autonomic balance, leading to blunted tachycardic response

-Subclinical myocarditis 

 

Causes of Relative Bradycardia in Infectious Diseases : mnemonic: BE CAREFUL -These Little Cold Epidemics 

  1. Brucellosis
    • Infection with Brucella melitensis leads to relative bradycardia due to inflammatory cytokines and increased vagal tone, despite high fever.
  2. COVID-19
    • Patients may exhibit relative bradycardia associated with myocardial injury and systemic inflammation, showing insufficient heart rate increase despite high fever and hypoxemia.
  3. Typhoid Fever
  4. Legionnaire's Diseasse
  5. Chlamydial Pneumonia
  6. Ebola Hemorrhagic Fever

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a history of fever, malaise, and abdominal discomfort for last one week. Physical examination reveals coated tongue, relative bradycardia and a hepatomegaly. NS-1 antigen is negative. What is the most likely fever pattern seen in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sustained fever

 

Explanation:

Sustained fever is characterized by a continuous elevated temperature that does not fluctuate significantly. It is commonly seen in typhoid fever, where the fever progressively rises in a stepwise manner in intial phase and then shows sustained fever 

Features of Sustained or continuous fever 

1. Temperature remains above normal throughout the day

2. Fluctuations do not exceed 1°C (or 1.5°F)

3. No return to baseline at any point during the day

 

Saddle back fever is seen in Dengue fever. Intermittent fever is seen in malaria where it returns to normal between the spikes. Remittent fever is where it fluctuates > 1 C but never comes back to normal like in infective endocarditis.

questions.text: Quotidian fever is seen with which of the following species of Plasmodium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A: Falciparum 

 

Explanation:

Quotidian fever refers to a fever pattern that occurs daily (i.e., every 24 hours), returning to baseline each day. It is typically associated with infections such as Plasmodium knowlesi malaria, early P. falciparum infection, and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Still's disease).

Malaria fever patterns

Type of Fever

Characteristics

Examples

Quotidian Fever

 

Fever occurs once every day, and it will touch the baseline.

P. falciparum, P. knowlesi

Tertian Fever 

Fever is occurring every 48 hours.

P. vivax, P. ovale

Quartan Fever 

Fever will occur after every 72 hours.

P. malariae

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a fever of 38.5°C (101.3°F) that has persisted for three weeks. He reports significant weight loss, night sweats, and fatigue. His medical history is unremarkable. On physical examination, he has splenomegaly and cervical lymphadenopathy. Which investigation would be the most appropriate next step in this patient's management?

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis

 

Explanation:

  • Given the patient's symptoms of prolonged fever, significant weight loss, night sweats, splenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy, a CT scan can help identify potential underlying causes such as infections, malignancies (e.g., lymphomas), or abscesses.
  • It provides a comprehensive view of the abdominal organs and lymphatic structures.

 

PUO-causes

Category

Common Causes

Other Causes

Infections
  • Tuberculosis (military or disseminated / extra-pulmonary)
  • Endocarditis (culture negative)
  • Deep-seated infections (abscesses, prostatitis, etc.)
  • Typhoidal and non-typhoidal Salmonella
  • Emerging Infections: HIV, Leishmaniasis, Melioidosis
  • Travelers: Malaria, Visceral leishmaniasis, Histoplasmosis

Neoplasms
  • Malignant lymphomas
  • Renal-cell carcinoma, hepatocellular cancer
  • Ovarian cancer, atrial myxoma
  • Castleman disease, brain tumors

Auto-inflammatory and Autoimmune Disorders
  • Giant-cell arteritis, Polymyalgia rheumatica (elderly)
  • Adult-onset Still's disease (younger)
  • Inflammatory bowel disease, certain types of uveitis, Behçet's syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, dermatomyositis, polymyositis
  • PAN, small vessel vasculitis, FMF

Miscellaneous
  • Granulomatous: Kikuchi disease, Sarcoidosis, Granulomatous hepatitis
  • Vascular: atrial myxoma, pulmonary emboli, hematomas
  • Endocrine: thyrotoxicosis, thyroiditis, Pheochromocytoma
  • Hematologic: HUS, TTP
  • Cirrhosis, Pancreatitis, Factitious fever
  • Drug fever (3-7% of febrile episodes in hospitalized patients; 1/3 due to antibiotics - beta-lactams)
  • DRESS, Hyperthermic drug syndromes (NMS, Serotonin syndrome)

 

Two stages of baseline tests followed by more specific tests, after which each abnormal result should be weighed carefully:

Two Stages of Baseline Tests

  • Baseline Set of Investigations:
    • Blood count with a differential cell count
    • Renal electrolytes and liver function tests
    • C-reactive protein (CRP) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
    • Clotting screen
    • Creatine kinase
    • At least two blood cultures (while not receiving antibiotics)
    • HIV test
    • Chest X-ray
    • Ultrasound of the abdomen
    • Urine dipstick
  • Second-Line Investigations:
    • Microbiological tests
    • Imaging
    • Biopsies

Note:

  • Early blanket testing for all possible aetiologies is inappropriate.
  • Each abnormal result should be weighed carefully.

 

Chest X-ray (Option A): Limited to evaluating respiratory causes and may miss abdominal pathologies.

 

Blood cultures (Option B) are important for detecting infections but may not identify structural causes of the patient's symptoms.

 

HIV test (Option D): Relevant for considering infectious etiologies but does not provide immediate insights into potential underlying structural abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered an autoinflammatory syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rheumatoid arthritis

 

Explanation:

 

Autoinflammatory disorders  means dysregulation of innate immunity (no autoantibodies)

Autoimmune disorders implies dysregulation of adaptive immunity (presence of T-cells, B-cells, autoantibodies)

Rheumatoid arthritis is classified as an autoimmune disease and RA factor and anti -CCP antibody that causes erosive arthritis. 

Familial Mediterranean fever, Adult-onset Still’s disease, and Cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes, are recognized as autoinflammatory syndromes. (Option A, B, D)

 

Non-infectious Inflammatory Disorder

Category

Examples

Systemic Rheumatic and Autoimmune Diseases
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Behçet's disease
  • Mixed connective-tissue disease
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Sjögren's syndrome
  • SLE
  • Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome(VKH Syndrome)

Vasculitis
  • Allergic vasculitis
  • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Giant cell vasculitis/polymyalgia rheumatica
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Kawasaki disease
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Takayasu arteritis

Granulomatous Diseases
  • Idiopathic granulomatous hepatitis, sarcoidosis

Autoinflammatory Syndromes (Option A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Adult-onset Still's disease
  • CAPS (cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes)
  • Familial Mediterranean fever
  • Hyper-IgD syndrome (HIDS, also known as mevalonate kinase deficiency)
  • PAPA syndrome (pyogenic sterile arthritis, pyoderma gangrenosum, and acne)
  • PFAPA syndrome (periodic fever, aphthous stomatitis, pharyngitis, adenitis)
  • SAPHO (synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, osteomyelitis)
  • TRAPS (tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome)

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a fever of 39°C that has persisted for the past five days. She reports severe muscle pain, nausea, and retroorbital pain. On examination, she has mild dehydration and a negative tourniquet test. Which of the following investigations would be most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: MAC ELISA for Dengue virus antibody

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C: MAC ELISA for Dengue virus antibody

 

Explanation:

In febrile phase of dengue ( day 1-3) NS1 has high sensitivity. In critical phase Day 4 - 6 , NS-1 antigen begins to decline and IgM starts rising. After day 7 ( recovery phase) IgM and IgG antibody is detected. Our case is for day 5 where Antibody detection would be best suited for confirmation of diagnosis. 

Hematocrit is done to evaluate for Dengue shock syndrome and is best prognostic test for dengue. Platelet count will deplete in DHF.

questions.text: What is the most common neurological complication during the course of dengue fever illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Encephalopathy

 

Explanation:

Encephalopathy is the most common neurological complication during course of dengue fever. It can be due to brain underperfusion due to shock or bleeeding or multi organ dysfunction. 

 

Dengue complications

Neurological
  • Dengue encephalopathy is most commonly encountered neurological complication of dengue virus 
    • linked primarily to dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome
    • EEG may show abnormalities such as burst suppression and seizures
    • CSF profiles typically remain normal.
    • Neuroimaging can be normal or reveal diffuse cerebral edema.

Cardiomyopathy

Dengue virus-induced dilated cardiomyopathy should always be considered if a dengue fever patient has refractory shock and signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure.

Hepatic injury
  • Liver involvement in dengue is a crucial feature
  • The effect ranges from an asymptomatic rise in liver enzymes to the development of ALF
  • The most common atypical manifestation reported was hepatitis

Pneumonia

 
  • Staphylococcus pneumonia is an important accompanying problem seen in dengue patient
  • co-infection between dengue and influenza can result in exacerbation of pneumonia

Orchitis
  • Orchitis usually occurs together with epididymitis
  • Commonly seen in men between 14 and 35 years of age.

questions.text: A 30-year-old farmer presents with high-grade fever, retro-orbital pain, and severe calf muscle tenderness for the past 3 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Leptospirosis 

Leptospirosis is classically associated with fever + retro-orbital pain + intense myalgia, especially in the calves and lower back. Often occurs after exposure to contaminated water or animals (e.g., farmers, sewage workers).

Dengue also presents with retro-orbital pain and fever, but calf pain is not as prominent. Myalgia is generalized and accompanied by rash, thrombocytopenia, and hemoconcentration.

Zika virus presents with mild fever, rash, conjunctivitis, and joint pain — retro-orbital pain is rare, and severe calf pain is not a feature.

Typhoid fever causes step-ladder fever, abdominal symptoms, and relative bradycardia, but no retro-orbital pain or focal calf tenderness.

questions.text: Following a sudden outbreak of mystery fever in a South Indian village, several individuals from the same locality developed fever, headache, altered sensorium, and seizures. Which of the following is not true regarding this likely condition?

choices.text: The disease has been linked to Pteropus species as natural reservoirs
The condition often presents as rapidly progressive viral encephalitis
Human-to-human transmission has been documented in prior outbreaks

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Case fatality rate below 10%

 

Explanation:

Clinical features point to Nipah virus which is a zoonotic paramyxovirus with outbreak potential and high public health concern. It is transmitted from Pteropus bats to humans, often via contaminated fruits or intermediate hosts. It causes acute encephalitis with high neurovirulence and rapid clinical decline and CFR touching 40 to 75%.  It is present in body fluids like saliva and can be transmitted from person to person.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with fever, conjunctivitis, and a maculopapular rash after returning from a trip to Central America. Local health authorities comfirm antibodies to Zika virus infection. Which of the following is correct about this infection?

choices.text: Transmitted only through infected bodily fluids.
Complications include microcephaly and Guillain–Barré syndrome.
Reliable diagnosis via serology in the first week.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Complications include microcephaly and Guillain–Barré syndrome.

 

Explanation:

  • Zika virus (ZIKV) infection can lead to serious complications such as congenital microcephaly in newborns and Guillain–Barré syndrome in adults. 
  • The virus is primarily transmitted through mosquito bites and sexual contact, with an incubation period of 3–12 days, making option C the only correct statement.

 

Zika Virus

  • Transmission: (Option A ruled out)
    • Spread by Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes (daytime feeders).
    • Sexual transmission is possible.
  • Epidemiology:
    • Initially identified in Africa and Asia.
    • It has become an epidemic in the Caribbean and Central/South America since 2015.

Clinical features of ZIKA Infection

Feature

Description

Incubation period
  • 3–12 days (Option B ruled out)

Symptomatic presentation
  • Fever, arthralgia, conjunctivitis, maculopapular rash

Possible complications
  • Guillain–Barré syndrome
  • Congenital microcephaly

Other congenital issues
  • Cerebral calcification
  • Deafness
  • Vision problems
  • Joint contractures (arthrogryposis)
  • Hydrops fetalis
  • Growth retardation

Infection target
  • Neural progenitor cells

 

Workup for ZIKV Infection

 

Test Type

Findings

Routine blood tests

Possible leucopenia, thrombocytopenia, or elevated transaminases (often normal)

PCR test

Detects ZIKV in blood (first week) or urine (up to 14 days)

Serology

Retrospective diagnosis; cross-reactivity with other flaviviruses (Option D ruled out)

Plaque-reduction neutralisation testing

Detects virus-specific neutralising antibodies to differentiate primary infections.

 

Treatment of ZIKV Infection

  • Approach:
    • Supportive care (specifics not detailed).

Prevention of ZIKV Infection

Prevention Method

Recommendations

Mosquito bite prevention

Primary method to avoid infection

Sexual health precautions

Infected individuals: safe sex for 6 months

Delay pregnancy for 6 months

Asymptomatic travelers

Safe sex and avoid pregnancy for 2 months after returning

Vaccination status

No vaccine currently available

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with progressive bilateral lower limb weakness over the past 10 days after recovery from zika virus infection. On examination, he has flaccid paralysis and absent deep tendon reflexes in the affected limbs. CSF analysis shows cytoalbuminological dissociation. NCV test confirms a demyelinating pattern. Which diagnostic criteria are used to diagnose this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Brighton 

 

Explanation:

Post zika virus infection patient has developed bilateral flaccid weakness and absent deep tendon reflexes. CSF findings are albuminocytological dissociation (elevated protein with normal white cell count) and NCV has demyeliantion. All the highlighted text constitute Brighton criteria for diagnosis of gullian barre syndrome. Option B is for Multiple sclerosis and Option C and D for Normal pressure hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with fever, dry cough, and progressive shortness of breath. His CD4+ count is 150 cells/mm³. Chest X-ray shows bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of infection in this patient?

choices.text: Primary infection acquired from a contaminated water source
Airborne transmission from an infected individual
Ingestion of fungal spores from environmental reservoirs
Reactivation of a previously dormant infection acquired during childhood

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Airborne transmission from an infected individual

 

Explanation:

This patient with HIV and a low CD4+ count (150 cells/mm³), fever, dry cough, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray likely has Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia . PJP is a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals and iit s primarily transmitted via airborne spread from person to person. The organism is inhaled, leading to infection in the lungs, especially when immune defenses are weakened.

 

Pneumocystis jirovecii: Cause and Transmission

  • Opportunistic Pathogen:
    • Primarily affects immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS patients with CD4+ counts <200 cells/mm³).
  • Colonization in Healthy Individuals:
    • Common in healthy lungs; most children are exposed by age 4.
    • Reactivation in adults is possible from childhood exposure or new infections.
  • Airborne Transmission:
    • Spreads through person-to-person contact, especially in hospital settings.
    • Colonized individuals exhale the organism, contaminating the environment.
  • Reinfection vs. Reactivation:
    • Both reinfection with new strains and reactivation of dormant infection are possible causes of recurrent PCP.
  • Environmental Reservoir:
    • Exact environmental source unknown, but the organism has been found in air samples near infected patients.

 

Primary infection acquired from a contaminated water source (Option A): Pneumocystis jirovecii is not transmitted through water sources.

 

Ingestion of fungal spores from environmental reservoirs (Option C): There is no evidence suggesting transmission through ingestion of spores.

 

Reactivation of a previously dormant infection acquired during childhood (Option D): Partially correct but not the best answer. Although reactivation can occur, the question hints at new infection rather than reactivation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with HIV presents with low-grade fever, nonproductive cough, and progressive shortness of breath over the past month. His HRCT shows bilateral ground-glass opacities. Which of the following is not correct about the suspected oppurtunisitic infection?

choices.text: Use of steroids during treatment of this oppurtunistic infection
Crushed ping pong ball appearance on Gomori methamine stain

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cultured on Sabaroud dextrose agar

 

Explanation:

Pneumocystis jirovecii cannot be cultured using conventional laboratory culture methods. Hence Beta 1,3 D glucan, BAL staining with Gomori-methamine stain where the cyst wall is stained black. Due to intersttial pneumonia , Alveolar gradient is increased. During treatment cotrimoaxazole is used. But during treatment the release of inflammatory cytokines can lead to ARDS. Hence steroids are co-administered if PaO₂ < 70 mmHg or A–a gradient > 35 mmHg.

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic methods provides the highest sensitivity for confirming the presence of Pneumocystis jirovecii?

choices.text: Induced sputum and staining with gomori methamine stain

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Polymerase Chain Reaction 

 

Explanation:

  • PCR of BAL fluid is the most sensitive test for diagnosing Pneumocystis jirovecii, especially when direct microscopy is negative. It has sensitivity rates up to 96%.
  • IF study is highly specific but less sensitive 
  • Sequence is PCR> IF > Gomori methamine staining

questions.text: A 35 year old truck driver with AIDS is having CD4 count of 150 cells/ cu.mm. He has sulfa drug allergy. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient by nebulization route for prevention of this oppurtunisitic infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pentamidine

 

Explanation:

The first-line treatment as well as used for Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia is Tri methoprim/Sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) due to its high efficacy. In patients with sulpha drug allergy pentamidine nebulization can be done for prophylaxis. 

 

Treatment of Pneumocystis Jiroveci

Treatment

Administration

Indication

Pentamidine

IV: 4 mg/kg/day

For patients intolerant to TMP/SMX 

Atovaquone

Oral: 750 mg twice daily

Effective for mild to moderate PCP, fewer side effects 

Clindamycin + Primaquine

Combination therapy

For patients failing TMP/SMX or pentamidine 

Dapsone

Alone or with TMP

For prophylaxis and treatment in select cases

Caspofungin

Combination with low-dose TMP/SMX

For severe cases

Adjunctive Therapy like Corticosteroids: Recommended for moderate to severe PCP, especially with low oxygen levels (PaO2 < 70 mm Hg or oxygen saturation < 92%).
